summary: This is a Director's Awards nomination form for a team of prosecutors and investigators from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, recognizing their work on the Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell sex trafficking case. It details the multi-year investigation, the charges, the trial, and the convictions, highlighting the team's efforts to uncover a vast abuse scheme and secure justice for victims.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Described as Epstein's girlfriend, business partner, and co-conspirator who recruited, groomed, and enticed minor girls for abuse, and directly participated in abuse. She was arrested in July 2020, convicted in December 2021, and sentenced in June 2022.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The primary perpetrator of a sex trafficking and abuse scheme targeting minor girls from 1994 to 2004. He was arrested and charged in July 2019 but died by suicide before trial.

connections.description: Described as girlfriend, business partner, and co-conspirator in a sex trafficking and abuse scheme spanning years.

events.title: Epstein Arrest and Charges
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested and charged with sex trafficking and sex trafficking conspiracy.

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide while in custody awaiting trial.

events.title: Maxwell Arrest
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell was arrested on charges related to the sex trafficking scheme.

events.title: Maxwell Trial Conviction
events.description: Following a month-long trial, Ghislaine Maxwell was convicted of conspiracy to entice minors, conspiracy to transport minors, conspiracy to commit sex trafficking, and substantive counts of transportation and sex trafficking.

events.title: Maxwell Sentencing
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell was sentenced to an unspecified term of incarceration.

events.title: Period of Criminal Activity
events.description: The timeframe during which Epstein and Maxwell perpetrated their sex trafficking and abuse schemes against minor girls.

keyFacts: The investigation uncovered a sex abuse and trafficking scheme affecting 'more than one hundred' and 'hundreds' of minor victims, far beyond what was previously known.
The scheme operated like a 'pyramid scheme of sexual abuse,' where minor girls were paid to give sexualized massages to Epstein and were then paid to recruit other girls.

The investigative team executed over a dozen search warrants, seized dozens of electronic devices containing terabytes of data, and conducted more than 400 interviews of over 150 witnesses across multiple states and two foreign countries.
The prosecution team used 'novel applications of the sex trafficking and enticement statutes' to build their case against Maxwell and Epstein.
The document notes the investigation began after a media report described controversy over a prior state plea agreement for Epstein, implying the federal case was a corrective action.
